com.kuka.roboticsAPI.applicationModel.tasks
Class RoboticsAPITask

java.lang.Object
  com.kuka.roboticsAPI.applicationModel.tasks.RoboticsAPITask
All Implemented Interfaces:
IRoboticsAPITask
Direct Known Subclasses:
RoboticsAPIApplication, RoboticsAPIBackgroundTask
public abstract class RoboticsAPITask
extends java.lang.Object
implements IRoboticsAPITask

Base class for RoboticsAPI tasks.

Assumes a persistence engine with a application data source to access the persistent data through the convenience methods.

This element is not in its final state and might change in future versions.

dispose

public void dispose()
Disposes this task. Use this to dispose the RoboticsAPI and all of your resources.

Basic implementation calls getContext().dispose().

It is imperative that you call super.dispose() when you override this method like this: 

 @Override
 public void dispose()
 {
     try
     {
         // TODO your code
     }
     finally
     {
         super.dispose();
     }
 }

Specified by:
dispose in interface IRoboticsAPITask

getDevice

public final Device getDevice(java.lang.String controllerName,
                              java.lang.String deviceName)
Gets the device with the given name on the given controller. If no such controller or device is found, this method throws an exception.

Parameters:
controllerName - The controller name. If the name is null, all controllers are checked for the device and the first device on a controller which has the correct name is returned.
deviceName - The name of the device.
Returns:
The device with the given name on the specified controller.

getTaskFunction

public <T extends ITaskFunction> ITaskFunctionAccessor<T> getTaskFunction(java.lang.Class<T> functionClass)
Gets the task function accessor for the specified task function class.

This accessor provides access to the task function as well as the means to check whether the task function is available.
Please note that accessor will be returned by this function even if the task providing it is not running. Calling ITaskFunctionAccessor.get() of the returned accessor will result in an exception in this case. Please use methods ITaskFunctionAccessor.isAvailable() or ITaskFunctionAccessor.await(long, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit) to check if the function is accessible.

Example:
// get task function accessor
ITaskFunctionAccessor taskFunction = getTaskFunction(IMyTaskFunction.class);
// use task function
taskFunction.get().doSomething(); USE gettaskManager() AND CALL THE FUNCTION THERE!

Type Parameters:
T - The type of the task function.
Parameters:
functionClass - The task function class.
Returns:
The task function accessor for the given task function class.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if task engine is not defined for this task/application, or specified task function type is not known.

getTaskManager
